awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  An artificial intelligence system for autonomous numerical control programming for advanced manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to address the challenge of reshoring manufacturing given the technical skills gap crisis in the U.S. by helping increase the productivity of precision machinists and sparking greater interest in the field of precision manufacturing among new workforce entrants. Computer Numerical Control (CNC), the computer-automated management of machining tools’ operations, is a key process in precision manufacturing. Programming CNC machines requires professionals with vast and specialized technical skills. With fewer graduates of trade schools, CNC programming know-how has become a bottleneck to manufacturing operations, creating an urgent unmet need for a radically simplified and automated CNC programming workflow to improve accessibility to precision manufacturing. This project aims to develop an artificial intelligence tool to automate the CNC programming process, thereby helping ease the CNC programming bottleneck and fill the skills gap at reduced manufacturing time and costs. 

This project will expand research on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) for generative CNC programming in precision manufacturing. AI has the potential to automate various steps in the CNC programming workflow; however, this research has been limited to constrained machining conditions and has not focused on optimization procedures, thereby limiting its real-world applicability. This project expands this research to develop a commercially viable solution for the optimal cutting tool and machining parameter selection stage of CNC programming. Briefly, this project will address technical challenges of algorithm development and optimization to improve accurate selection of tool and machining parameters. The results will be validated on CNC machines. At the end of Phase I, a proof-of-concept solution will be developed to automate the optimal cutting tool and machining parameters selection for CNC drilling and milling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Computer Numerical Control (CNC), the computer-automated management of machining tools? operations, is a key process in manufacturing. CNC machines are the dominant technology for manufacturing due to the growing demand for precision machining from high-growth industries like Aerospace & Defense, Automotive, Medtech, and Machinery Equipment. Programming CNC machines requires professionals who have vast and specialized technical skills. However, fewer people are attending trade schools, and by 2028, 2.4 million skilled manufacturing jobs are predicted to be unfilled. Thus, CNC programming is becoming a bottleneck to manufacturing operations, and there is an urgent unmet need for a radically simplified and automated CNC programming workflow to increase accessibility to precision machining. To ease the bottleneck and fill the skills gap, this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project funded research to assess the technical feasibility of developing an artificial intelligence tool to automate the CNC programming process, specifically related to optimal cutting tool and machining parameters selection. 

Intellectual Merit:

This project addresses the U.S. manufacturing skills gap crisis by expanding research on the use of artificial intelligence for generative CNC programming in precision machining. Prior research shows that AI has the potential to automate various steps in the CNC programming workflow; however, this research has been limited to constrained machining conditions and has not always focused on optimization procedures thereby limiting its real-world applicability. The work completed in this SBIR Phase I expanded on these preliminary findings to assess the technical viability of automating the optimal cutting tool and machining parameter selection stage of CNC programming. This project helped address technical challenges of algorithm development and optimization related to optimal tool and machining parameters selection. The results of this Phase I project were deemed favorable relative to project milestones. Furthermore, a software prototype was successfully developed. Project outcomes have helped secure a strong foundation upon which additional R&D can be undertaken with the goal of developing a commercially-ready solution for end-to-end autonomous CNC programming.

Broader Impacts:

Autonomous CNC programming solutions hold the potential to offer broader societal and economic benefit by helping reduce manufacturing time and costs. Autonomous CNC programming has broad applicability across Commercial, Government, and Academia, in a range of end market applications such as Aerospace & Defense, MedTech, and other high precision products. Furthermore, such solutions are a critical step in addressing the challenge of reshoring manufacturing given the technical skills gap crisis in the U.S. by helping increase the productivity of CNC machinists and sparking greater interest in this field among new workforce entrants. It is clear that the manufacturing landscape is shifting to more automation, and a commercially-ready solution (developed upon the foundation secured via this SBIR Phase I) could help train the next generation of AI-augmented machinists.

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Tanmay Aggarwal
